Also try this:
Put a bar magnet on a piece of blank paper.
Place a magnetic compass around one of the poles.
Draw a dot where the needle marks South and a small triangle where it marks North.
Slide the compass over until the triangle is touching the new South needle. Draw another small triangle where the needle points North.
Connect the dots/triangles.

Repeating this process over and over, you map out the electric field lines on the paper.

The force applied to this charges(or this little iron stuff or little magnets) is
F=nq[v×B] (vector term)
|F| = nq|[v×B]|

Where q= electric charge
n= number of charges
v= velocity of charge (vector)
B= external magnetic field OR magnetic field of big magnet


Where B= (Mu/4π) ( i dL×r/|r³|) {vector}

i =electric current
dL=length of area which creates magnetic field
r =distance where you want to find magnetic field.
